The cells of Chromohalobacter canadensis are short, rod-shaped, and motile with a single polar flagellum. They typically measure around 0.5-0.8 μm in width and 1.2-2.0 μm in length.

This species is classified within the genus Chromohalobacter, which belongs to the family Halomonadaceae in the class Gammaproteobacteria. Chromohalobacter canadensis is known to be moderately halophilic, requiring between 3-20% (w/v) NaCl for optimal growth, with the preferred range being 5-10% NaCl.

Physiologically, Chromohalobacter canadensis is capable of utilizing a variety of organic compounds as carbon and energy sources, including carbohydrates, organic acids, and amino acids. It is also able to reduce nitrate to nitrite, but cannot reduce nitrite further.

The optimal growth temperature for Chromohalobacter canadensis is reported to be around 37°C, and the optimal pH range is between 7.0-8.0. This species has been found in saline environments, such as saline soils and hypersaline aquatic habitats.
